ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: Yet man still wants to deny what is ahead of him,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: Yet man is sceptical of what is right before him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: But man desires to persist in his evil ways.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: In fact, people want to have eternal life in this world.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: In fact man wishes to commit evil in front of Him!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Nay! Man desires to break out ahead of himself.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Nay! man desires to give the lie to what is before him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: Nay, but man desires to continue on as a libertine,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: But man would fain deny what is before him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: Yet man wants to deny what is ahead of him:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Aye! man desireth that he may sin before him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: Indeed, man desires to go on living viciously.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: But man wishes to do wrong (even) in the time in front of him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Nay! (Man denies Resurrection and Reckoning. So) he desires to continue committing sins.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: Rather, the human desires to continue in his immorality,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: But man wants to deny what is ahead of him.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: But man desires to continue in sin.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [75:5] Nay, but man desires to deny (li-yafjura: the lām is extra, and the subjunctive mood is because of an implied [preceding] an, ‘that’) what lies ahead of him, namely, the Day of Resurrection, as is indicated by:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (But man) the disbelieving man: 'Adiyy Ibn Rabi'ah (would fain deny what is before him) would fain to indulge in his evil acts and delay his repentance; it is also said this means: he would fain to engage in evil deeds and indecencies in his future days.
